instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: MacBookPro Retina <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>. fluctuate at 200mAmp
threads.message: I got a liquid damage <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A. It was corroded near <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> and <CHIP>U8330</CHIP>. And initially was stucked at 120mAmp. After cleaning replacing <RESISTOR>R8185</RESISTOR>, It stopped taking 120mAmp but now when power on takes 180-220mAmp for 1 second only then goes to zero. i also check at same time it produces S0 rails and Powergood signals just for 1 Sec.  I didn't found any other liquid damage or short circuit. check SPI Rom and related signal all are present and normal. when it is in off state, only have S5 rails. <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWORK</SIGNAL> goes off.  I looked for some other stuffs but i have admit i don't know where to look?

threads.title: MacBookPro Retina <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>. fluctuate at 200mAmp
threads.message:
For liquid spilled boards, is recommended to reball SMC.
<SIGNAL>CPU_VCSST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> pulsing?
Also check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.

Try to start in SMC bypass mode too.
